Comments like these sadden me greatly. FF 8, 9 and X were all great, even better than 7 in their own ways. I think it is still a good game and most of what makes 7 so highly praised today is the nostalgia factor. 7 was the first of its kind and did a lot of things well, but I wouldn't say it was the best FF game by a long shot. 

I would agree that the newer games have been lackluster. Square Enix is too focused on making new features than creating lovable characters and immersive plots.

snippet.textDisplay:
Nostalgia plays a part in everyone's life, and for many this was their first Final Fantasy. However, it was also perhaps one of the more surreal. While all the PSX era games had static, pre-rendered backgrounds, I'd argue that this game had perhaps the most colorful, unique, and creative of the bunch. Forgotten city was so mysterious in its looks, the song only compounding such a bizarre location (what the shit lived in that giant conch?!). The very sound of the OST had such a unique flare, perhaps due to restrictions, giving it a more artificial, if unnatural sound other Square rpgs had at the time (Legends of Mana!) which in my opinion made the experience all the more enthralling. 

The world map had a grey tint to it by the end, with the somber music and the fact the world was ending all fit so perfectly together, like many things did. (other ff games did this too, even 6 before it, but still it worked!) Everyone will have their favorites, but this game did a lot of things right at the right time, from unique characters like Red XIII, to the bizarre enemies that covered the world. As others said above me, this game brought JRPGs to their countries, that wasn't by mistake.

Final Fantasy 6 is perhaps one of my favorites, and I can understand people hating on 7 after the shift from sprites(or believing others loved the game simply because it was 3d, even if characters looked pretty bad and it always bothered me that they had no mouth) but even with the weak push when it came to the polygons.. the background, atmosphere, and many mechanics just worked and elevated it from such faults to the point where I could forgive it

 It's not all nostalgia, and I'd disagree when you say it isn't the best "By a long shot", because I'd put it right up there with 6, 8, 9, and Tactics, which perhaps had one of the best stories imo. Strange, pre-rendered machinery filled several backgrounds, ghosts in the abandoned train-yard, the swinging guillotine guys in the abandoned mansion.. the thrill of finally climbing the Shinra tower... finding Lucrecia's Cave... looking for that damn key item at the dig site. All of it just created a strange, yet unforgettable world later games just didn't do the same (though don't get me wrong, they did things in their own way, and did it quite well). The setting of the game opened up so many possibilities for uniqueness that they used. The other games setup a very specific theme and stuck with it, it was less of a mess and more direct, which is fine, but 7 kept that perfect blend of fantasy and technology that 6 was pushing as well, while at the same time being sloppy, yet surprisingly well kept. 

TLDR: It just saddens me when I see comments like this when it truly boils down to ones own opinion, and what they got out of their experience with this, and any other game. I've played every Final Fantasy (except 12) Yes, even 11 and 14 quite passionately, we're not all blind by nostalgia when there is truly something to enjoy. Frankly, you're making it seem like you simply know something everyone else doesn't, but it doesn't quite work that way. I spent just as many hours in 8, 9, and 10 as I have in 7, each a big part of my life. Opinions.

We know what we like, and I'd put 7 right up there even with its lacking story, the comical villain that was Sephiroth, and the disgusting yet silly character of Don Corneo.. why? Because the game is fun, and that's what matters in the end.

Cheers for a three year necro.

snippet.textDisplay:
For me the power of this piece isn't so much the first time you come here (Aeris' death) but the second. Her death is confusing at first and seemingly pointless, but when you return, you learn why she did what she did, and what she sought to accomplish. Even though you have the answers now, the despair remains; we learn that, even if meteor is stopped, there may still be no hope for humanity.

"Meteor, weapon, everything will disappear. Perhaps, even ourselves."

Truly a chilling implication.

snippet.textDisplay: Final Fantasy VII changed my life, like so many other gamers. I wasn't new 2 games, I wasn't even new 2 RPG's. I'd been gaming since I was 4 & I played this at about 15. But the effect on me as a person was like a shell-shock. The music is key. It is like remembering a place because of a smell. Music helps you remember an emotion. That first time you played, the first time the music tweaked your soul. It never leaves you..& it never will. This more than anything is why 7 will always be the best.

snippet.textDisplay:
I hope they don't remake FFVII. It would only be a further raping of the game. You don't see Nintendo going around remaking Mario, Metroid or Zelda games. Enhancements, yes, but they further the franchises and continue to make great games. Square-Enix can't make a good game anymore, so the just continue to milk the old great games.

Anyway. They can't remake this game, and keep the same scope. It's just not possible to make a game of that size. It would be too massive.

snippet.textDisplay:
@TheRetroPrime Ocarina of Time isn't a RPG, so it's hard to compare to the two. And taste plays a much larger role, along with nostalgia. FFVII is my favorite game of all time. Is it the best? No, it's not. There is no best game, and I'm getting sick and hearing over and over that OoT is the best game ever made. 

So stop this damn tribalism, and appreciate both games, as they are clearly (no matter which one is superior) superb games.
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: FF7 haters are a reactionary measure by an indifferent group of people who were uncomfrotable with the fact that certain people have been content to soundly see perfection where imperfections lie.  As has been said already; nothing is perfect.  And though I myself, when younger, might have felt a slight twinge at the game being presumed almost 'perfect' in normal esteem, this was dispelled when the hate force began to rise.  This game is clearly closer to flawless than it is flawed.

@riznich
Say what you will. I don't think Final Fantasy VI is the best game ever. It's not the best RPG ever, either. I prefer it over the rest in the series, but saying it is the most overrated game in the series is not true. Final Fantasy VII and Legend of Zelda: Ocarina of Time are the most overrated games ever made, therefore rendering your point moot. They're not bad games by any stretch, but they aren't perfect, as most reviews of them suggest.

I think the first impact of this song came from the fact that this was the first new song you'd heard for a hell of a long time.
You'd gotten used to the town music, overworld music, action music, battle music, boss music etc...then suddenly, this tune comes out of no-where and you're like "Bwuh? This is.....interesting."

Of course, nostalgia now dictates this music is important for another reason.

snippet.textDisplay: well objectively, the storyline is broken, the characters are underdeveloped and the filler side-quests kill the experience. plus the music was sub-par for the console and generation it was on. just listen to castlevania SOTN, panzer dragoon, and countless other sega Saturn titles. FFVII's music half the time was very anti-atmospheric and sounded like it was done on a 1980's keyboard. overall, the music is like the game. shallow, sub-par and overrated. it just wasnt in any way, a "great" game.

snippet.textDisplay:
FFX was good. Would've been worlds better if Tidus wasn't there.

I can't believe anyone said X is equal to VII though...thats just not right. No game, ever, in history, will be equal to VII. Nothing could ever hold a candle to FFVII. In terms of plot development, twists, musical score, character development, and in-game content (secrets and weapons, that sort of deal) FFVII is still definitely my favorite game to date.

Even in the world of COD Modern Warfare, Oblivion and Assassin's Creed.
